text.p: Spanish government bonds and the peseta moved higher on Monday, fuelled by expectations of monetary easing, traders said.
They said these hopes have been compounded by more optimism on upcoming inflation data.

The CPI is expected to rise to 3.9 percent year-on-year in August from 3.7 percent in July, implying that a recent hike in taxes on tobacco and alcohol has not had such a large effect on prices as originally anticipated, they said.
Some think a rate cut could emerge as soon as Friday, when the Bank of Spain's regular repo auction takes place, they said.
